column4: if i set up a static ip in /etc/network/interfaces, it works great...until i reboot, has something changed concerning static ips in 12.04?
well, in general it seems to uses dhcp again though a few days ago i had the weird effect of my pc telling me i had x.x.x.69 (while the fixed one is x.x.x.100) and i could still ping 69 &100
but basically the system thinks (and acts) like it uses dhcp again
how're you determining it's using dhcp again?
well it's a guess based on the fact that it gets the same address it had before i made it static. I have not monitored actual network traffic to see dhcp requests going out
also, if i restart the networking and network-manager (or combination thereof), it goes back to the static one
so ifconfig doesn't show the IP you set it to be?
indeed, until i restart the /etc/init.d/networking & network manager
ye seems to be ok then
maybe networkmanager is getting in the way, hum
any chance that network manager is doing something it shouldn't? (i have no clue how it works)
is it actually used for anything else or would it be safe/possible to shut network manager down?
mostly it's used for wireless network management
you use wireless networks with this box?
ah, it's on a desktop computer so not a problem
you could try disabling networkmanager from starting at bootup, reboot and see if that helps
